DISCHARGE SUMMARY AZI01HL DISCHARGE SUMMARY TLANDSEUSS , CHERE C UNIT NUMBER : 083-97-79 ADMISSION DATE : 09/15/1998 PRINCIPAL DIAGNOSIS : Wolfe-Parkinson White Syndrome . Atrial fibrillation , coronary artery disease , hypertension , dementia , and diabetes . HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS : His cardiac risk factors include : hypercholesterolemia , hypertension and insulin dependent diabetes mellitus . He has a history of chest pain and in January 1993 underwent a cardiac catheterization at Ph University Of Medical Center which revealed an occluded right coronary artery with distal filling via left to right collaterals , a large left anterior descending with a 40-50% proximal stenosis and a co-dominant left circumflex with mild disease . He subsequently had an echocardiogram in December 1994 which showed normal left ventricular size and systolic function . He subsequently had an adenosine sestamibi in February 1997 which was negative for ischemia or infarction . In December 1994 he had a paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia presenting with palpitations . He was diagnosed with Wolfe Parkinson White Syndrome . He underwent an electrophysiology study which identified an accessory pathway with multiple attempts at ablation by Dr. Slusslashgodle which were unsuccessful . He had mild congestive heart failure and was treated with an increased dose of Lasix . An echocardiogram showed an ejection fraction of approximately 50% and mild to moderate mitral regurgitation . He was discharged home but returned on 9/13/98 with worsening palpitations on and off . He denied any associated chest pain or dyspnea and he ruled out for a myocardial infarction . Prior to transfer he did have one episode of chest pain during the night without electrocardiogram changes . PAST MEDICAL HISTORY : Hypertension , hypercholesterolemia , diabetes mellitus , depression , prostate cancer status post surgery . Sotalol 160 mg bid . Atenolol 25 mg bid . Prilosec 20 mg qd . Propulsid 10 mg qd . NPH and CZI insulin . Resulin 400 mg qd . Lisinopril 10 mg bid . Lasix 60 mg qd . There was also a question of an allergy to Prednisone which he said causes eye swelling . PHYSICAL EXAM : His lungs were clear throughout . His apical impulse was nondisplaced with a regular rate and rhythm , normal S1 and S2 but not S3 or S4 . His abdomen was benign . Femoral pulses were 2+ bilaterally without bruits and he had pedal edema bilaterally . LABORATORY DATA : BUN 18 , creatinine 1.8 , magnesium 1.5 , cholesterol 154 with an HDL 41 , LDL 100 . His creatinine phosphokinase was 42 . His electrocardiogram showed sinus bradycardia with a delta wave and an intraventricular conduction delay consistent with Wolf Parkinson White Syndrome . There were also nonspecific ST-T wave abnormalities . Given his known coronary artery disease and his recent heart failure and chest pain a cardiac catheterization was indicated prior to proceeding to an electrophysiology study . His initial cardiac catheterization had to be postponed given the possibility of an allergy to Prednisone . He was seen by Nnoatal Hospital Center who felt that he could be safely treated with Solumedrol rather than Prednisone together with Benadryl and the use of low ionic contrast medium . Accordingly the patient underwent uneventful cardiac catheterization on 9/17/98 which revealed a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 25 and a left ventricular end diastolic pressure of 20 . His right coronary artery was occluded and filled distally via left to right collaterals . His left ventriculogram showed preserved systolic function and mild mitral regurgitation . The patient then underwent an electrophysiology study on 9/20/98 . There was no inducible supraventricular tachycardia but he did have evidence of a left lateral bypass tract . Mapping of the mitral anulus confirmed the location of the bypass tract . Radiofrequency ablation was applied there and resulted in the elimination of the preoperatively-excitation . There were no complications . Following the procedure there was no further evidence of wide complex tachycardia . There were 15 atrial runs the longest of which was 13 beats at a rate of 100 . He also underwent a post-procedural echocardiogram which showed an ejection fraction of 61% with mild mitral regurgitation and left atrial enlargement at 45mm . Following the procedure his QT interval was noted to be prolonged to approximately .55 seconds . After the procedure he was started on Heparin and loaded on Coumadin for a period of the next 3-4 weeks following radiofrequency ablation . Finally , his dementia appeared to worsen following receiving medications for agitation during his EP study . Accordingly he was seen by Neurology who felt that there was no evidence of a secondary process . He did have a head CT which showed no evidence of a bleed or stroke . CONDITION ON DISCHARGE : He was discharged in stable condition on 9/23/98 . He will have a visiting nurse to see him on Iat . FOLLOW-UP : MEDICATIONS ON DISCHARGE : Atenolol 25 mg bid . Sotalol 120 mg bid . Lasix 60 mg qd . Ecotrin 1 qd ( on hold until off of Coumadin ) . Coumadin 5 mg qhs or as directed for four weeks . Oxybutynin 5 mg qd . Resulin 400 mg qd . AO R.
